problem.display_name: Electric potential energy: a property of what%3F

text.p: A charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline] is at a location [mathjaxinline]\vec{r}_{\rm f}[/mathjaxinline] in an electric field [mathjaxinline]E(\vec{r}_{\rm f})[/mathjaxinline]. Which of the following statements is (are) true?

choice.text: a) electric potential energy is a property of the electric field[/mathjaxinline]E[mathjaxinline]
b) electric potential energy is a property of the charge[/mathjaxinline]q[mathjaxinline].
c) electric potential energy is the property of an electric charge[/mathjaxinline]q[mathjaxinline]in an electric field[/mathjaxinline]E(r_f)
d) electric potential energy may change when a charge moves in an electric field.

solution.font: a) it is wrong to say that electric potential energy is a property of the electric field; strictly speaking it is a property of the charge and the field; b) it is common to speak of the 'electric potential energy of a charge,' but it is really the potential energy of a charge in some particular electric field, so this answer is not satisfactory. c) True. Electric potential energy is a property of a charge in an electric field. A change of the value of either, changes the magnitude of the electric potential energy. d) This is correct. An electrostatic field [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline] will accelerate a charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline], increasing or decreasing its kinetic energy and consequently decreasing or increasing its electric potential energy.
